Journal.Title: Environmental health : a global access science source

Article.ArticleTitle: A cohort study evaluating the risk of stroke associated with long-term exposure to ambient fine particulate matter in Taiwan.

AbstractText: Evidences have shown that the stroke risk associated with long-term exposure to particulate matter with an aerodynamic diameter of ≤2.5 μm (PM<sub>2.5</sub>) varies among people in North America, Europe and Asia, but studies in Asia rarely evaluated the association by stroke type. We examined whether long-term exposure to PM<sub>2.5</sub> is associated with developing all strokes, ischemic stroke and hemorrhagic stroke.

The retrospective cohort study consisted of 1,362,284 adults identified from beneficiaries of a universal health insurance program in 2011. We obtained data on air pollutants and meteorological measurements from air quality monitoring stations across Taiwan in 2010-2015. Annual mean levels of all environmental measurements in residing areas were calculated and assigned to cohort members. We used Cox proportional hazards models to estimate hazard ratio (HR) and 95% confidence interval (CI) of developing stroke associated with 1-year mean levels of PM<sub>2.5</sub> at baseline in 2010, and yearly mean levels from 2010 to 2015 as the time-varying exposure, adjusting for age, sex, income and urbanization level.

During a median follow-up time of 6.0 years, 12,942 persons developed strokes, 9919 (76.6%) were ischemic. The adjusted HRs (95% CIs) per interquartile range increase in baseline 1-year mean PM<sub>2.5</sub> were 1.03 (1.00-1.06) for all stroke, 1.06 (1.02-1.09) for ischemic stroke, and 0.95 (0.89-1.10) for hemorrhagic stroke. The concentration-response curves estimated in the models with and without additional adjustments for other environmental measurements showed a positively linear association between baseline 1-year mean PM<sub>2.5</sub> and ischemic stroke at concentrations greater than 30 μg/m<sup>3</sup>, under which no evidence of association was observed. There was an indication of an inverse association between PM<sub>2.5</sub> and hemorrhagic stroke, but the association no longer existed after controlling for nitrogen dioxide or ozone. We found similar shape of the concentration-response association in the Cox regression models with time-varying PM<sub>2.5</sub> exposures.

Long-term exposure to PM<sub>2.5</sub> might be associated with increased risk of developing ischemic stroke. The association with high PM<sub>2.5</sub> concentrations remained significant after adjustment for other environmental factors.
